items.title: Wrong definition of __CV_INFO_PDB70_format__  in PE.parse_debug_directory function
Licence inconsitency - MIT or proprietary?
items.body:
I was pointed out by the FSF that pefile is licensed ambiguously:
- https://pypi.org/project/pefile/ states it is licensed under the MIT license
- the archive contains a copy of MIT license,
- but `pefile.py` states a different terms, namely, "All rights reserved".

The FSF takes this as ["in other words, it's proprietary."](https://savannah.gnu.org/task/?15146#comment1)

Please change the licence header in all relevant files to state it is MIT licensed. Thanks.

items.title: Generating a map of an executable
items.body:
Hello!
For an RE project, I need to analyze a PE executable and create a complete map, something like:

```
0x00000000-0x00001000 PE header
0x00001000-0x00001200 section table
    0x00001000-0x00001020 section table entry .text
    ....
0x00001200-0x00002000 unknown (padding?)
0x00002000-0x00010000 section .text
...
```

As far as I understand, pefile doesn't readily support this use case, nor have I found any other tool that could do this easily (correct me if I'm wrong!)

As such, I intend to fork pefile and add this functionality. I would like to ask whether you would be interested in merging it back upstream (assuming the code isn't complete shit), or whether it is out of scope of the project.

items.title: Potential improvement to bounds check
items.body:
I am just reviewing the implementation of `get_memory_mapped_image()` due to a weird PE file I'm parsing.

There is a [bounds check](https://github.com/erocarrera/pefile/blob/2286e9856ccbd5d1f82dd16d5a1526b2a90e63da/pefile.py#L4266) to ensure the section size isn't bigger than the total data available.

However, this doesn't take into account the offset into the file.  For example in a 1000 byte PE file it is not possible to read 500 bytes from offset 900.

Should this check instead be:

```
if section.PointerToRawData + section.SizeOfRawData > len(self.__data__):
    ...
```

Or am I missing something obvious?

items.title: pe.TimeDateStamp and /Brepro flag
items.body:
Hi,

Just for information: if a pe.DIRECTORY_ENTRY_DEBUG struct has a Type of 0x10, then windbg preview considers pe.TimeDateStamp as a build ID, not a valid timestamp. VS2013 with /Brepro just sets the TimeDateStamp to 0xFFFFFFFF and does not add the entry, but MS pe files have it (if you change an existing entry type to 0x10 of a regular pe file, then windbg preview adds the warning).

I dont really know how (and if) you can render this information in pefile, but it may be useful for malware analysts/tools : build IDs may in some cases seem "valid" and I did not found any other way to differentiate them.

Cheers

items.title: Multiple version information entries
items.body:
**Problem:**
Some PE files may have multiple VS_VERSION_INFO entries. However, currently pefile only parses the first entry found.

The problem arises due to this line:
https://github.com/erocarrera/pefile/blob/29d49621d19bf885f90af267146a204523d10b0f/pefile.py#L3101-L3106

Possible change:
```
for rsrc_entry in last_entry.directory.entries[0].directory.entries:
    rt_version_struct = None
    try:
        rt_version_struct = rsrc_entry.data.struct
    except:
        # Maybe a malformed directory structure...?
        # Lets ignore it
        pass

    if rt_version_struct is not None:
        self.parse_version_information(rt_version_struct)
```

However, if we want to dump multiple version information, further changes in `parse_version_information()` is required, since `self.FileInfo` is re-initialized inside it. Otherwise, the previous version information parsed will be overwritten on the next parsing iteration.
Therefore, `self.FileInfo` will need to be re-structured if we want to apply the fix above in order to dump multiple version information.

I haven't been able to find a reference on how Windows decides exactly which version information gets displayed in _Properties_. If someone finds a reference to it please kindly share it here.

**File information from VirusTotal (malware):**
https://www.virustotal.com/#/file/392f40778b3a67601e6a00021c2f8ee715b23ef50298a5d73c033bea34cd837c/detection

items.title: Add option to disable malformation detection without the need to manually call full_load()
items.body:
On big executable (typically installers of hundreds megabytes), PE `__init__` method can be very slow (>30 seconds). After profiling it appears that this is caused by the detection of possible malformations (the counting each byte occurence through the whole file).

Using `fast_load=True` disable this detection but also the parsing of usefull informations, hence the need to manually call `full_load` after PE object creation. It could be handy (and maybe clearer) to have a dedicated options to disable such detection.

For comparison, the whole duration of PE creation using `fast_load=True` followed by a call to `full_load` is less than half a second while the duration of PE creation without `fast_load` is > 30 seconds.

An alternative would be to only disable malformation detection when `fast_load=True`.

items.title: question about contains_rva
items.body:
Hello, I have a question about the `contains_rva` function in the `SectionStructure` (https://github.com/erocarrera/pefile/blob/master/pefile.py#L1098)

> Check whether there's any section after the current one that starts before the calculated end for the current one, if so, cut the current section's size to fit in the range up to where the next section starts.

Would there be a valid executable file (eg the Windows loader accepts it) that has this property or is it to properly handle malformed files?

The corkami PE wiki (https://corkamiwiki.github.io/PE#Misc_VirtualSize) doesn't appear to say anything about it, it only says (related):

> A section can have a null VirtualSize: in this case, only the SizeOfRawData is taken into consideration.
> - `nullvirt` has a section with a null VirtualSize and a non-null SizeOfRawData.

items.title: Error for value returned from get_overlay_data_start_offset()
items.body:
The current implementation of get_overlay_data_start_offset() includes the VirtualAddress and Size of the IMAGE_DIRECTORY_ENTRY structures, but that leads to an incorrect offset for the overlay of the file.  Here are two examples where the offset is calculated incorrectly:

https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/3096e39df63c0be68746ea3bbe528c067b6eb45e2d61cc167712c3b1e0966be3/analysis/, the overlay offset listed by VT corresponds to the IMAGE_DIRECTORY_ENTRY_SECURITY structure, which makes sense for certificate information, as digital signatures must be overlays.  However, the pefile module reports no overlay for this file, as the IMAGE_DIRECTORY_ENTRY_SECURITY VirtualAddress is equal to the largest section.PointerToRawData + section.SizeOfRawData, and the Size is the number of bytes from this VirtualAddress to the end of the file.

https://www.virustotal.com/en/file/307a69414b203f1116db677b8bc07130ae2b72cf33cf2ae5a39bf1bd484b587c/analysis/, the overlay offset listed by VT is the offset produced by the largest section.PointerToRawData + section.SizeOfRawData in the file, 14848, but the pefile module reports it as a larger value of 26176, as all of the IMAGE_DIRECTORY_ENTRY structures have virtual addresses larger than the largest section.PointerToRawData + section.SizeOfRawData.

items.title: future module not automatically installed by pip
items.body:
When I try to install downloaded pefile-2016.3.4 with pip I get this traceback:

```
» pip install -e /tmp/pefile-2016.3.4                                                                         
Obtaining file:///tmp/pefile-2016.3.4
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pefile-2016.3.4/setup.py", line 13, in <module>
        import pefile
      File "/tmp/pefile-2016.3.4/pefile.py", line 26, in <module>
        from past.builtins import cmp
    ImportError: No module named 'past'

    ----------------------------------------
Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pefile-2016.3.4
```

The issue here is circular dependency:
- `pefile` module depends on `future`
- `pip install` should install `future` automatically
- however `setup.py` imports version from `pefile` module before pip is able to install `future` module

What steps will reproduce the problem?

Instead, I get a locked file and I'm not able to make any modification in the

OS: Windows
Python 2.6

Please provide any additional information below.

Im running with exactly 246 files and in a certain step I verify if all of them 
are a PE file.
Something like this:

def IsExecutableFile( SrcPath ):   
    try:
        pefile.PE( SrcPath, fast_load = True )

32 (0x20)

Filipe

items.title: file/mmap handler not closed on __parse__ success - query
items.body:
```

What steps will reproduce the problem?
Run as follows (you will need notepad.exe in the same dir this is run from or 
any valid pe file (change filename appropriately)):

import pefile
import os
pe=pefile.PE('notepad.exe')
os.system("del notepad.exe")

What is the expected output? What do you see instead?
The following error is printed (by del) and the file is not deleted:
"The process cannot access the file because it is being used by another 
process."

What version of the product are you using? On what operating system?
pefile version: 1.2.10-114
Operating System: Windows XP Professional SP3

Please provide any additional information below.
This may not be an issue, it is similar the problem described in issue 26 but 
in this case it occurs when the pefile module does not except - i.e. 
__parse__() is successful - possibly this is as intended.

To avoid this issue I can call the pefile.PE close fn:
pe=pefile.PE('file.dll')
pe.close()
os.system("del file.dll")

Is this the expected way for pefile to function - i.e. should I be calling the 
pefile.PE close() fn in my script after calling pefile.PE to close the mmap 
handler?  I had a quick look at the pefile examples and don't see the close 
function being called.  Calling close() in my scripts seems a little misleading 
since it doesn't really close the pefile PE object as I'd expect since only the 
mmap handler is closed i.e. this works fine:

pe=pefile.PE('file.dll')
pe.close()
print pe.FileInfo

Alternatively I can add self.close() to the try block in pefile.PE init method:
        try:
            self.__parse__(name, data, fast_load)
            self.close()
        except:
            self.close()
            raise

I don't understand the impact of adding self.close() to the pefile.PE init 
method though i.e. will it affect the functionality of other pefile.PE 
functions that could normally be called after pefile.PE()?

I'd really appreciate your feedback on this before modifying our scripts.

Thank you very much

```

Original issue reported on code.google.com by `robbinc...@gmail.com` on 2 Dec 2011 at 4:29

items.title: mmap files left open on Python 2.5.x (with latest r112 trunk and r111 too)
items.body:
```
PE() creates a mmap file.
The mmap is never closed on python 2.5.x because mmap.mmap is a factory 
function and not a class. The behavior changed in 2.6 and mmap.mmap is now a 
class.
The attached patch does two things:
- first it ensures with a finally that PE.close() is always called
- second it does systematically closing self.__data__ if and only if the mmap 
data where loaded from a file
In fact if I passed a data arg instead of a file, I would not want my data to 
be closed without me knowing it.
a bit hackish but it takes care of the various cases nicely imho.

Thanks for pefile :)

```
